Ronald Reagan and Jane Wyman divorced due to Wyman's affair with a costar Lew Ayres, her partner in Belinda. After learning of the affair, Reagan was willing to accept her back from her, but the divorce proceeded at Wyman's request.

Ronald Reagan once boasted that he and Wyman would end their days together, but it didn't take long after the wedding vows were exchanged in 1940 for things to go awry. After testifying before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, Reagan returned home to find that Wyman had packed his belongings to her and placed them in her car.

After Wyman had disclosed the details of her affair de ella with Lew Ayres, her costar de ella in “Johnny Belinda,” Reagan told the press that he knew his wife de ella needed to have a fling and he intended for her to have it. Despite his leniency and hope for reconciliation, the divorce came in 1948.

She filed for divorce in 1948, and it was granted in 1949. According to actress Patricia Neal, Reagan was deeply hurt.

"It was, you know, just terrible because I was so unhappy," she said in an interview. "He was alone in an apartment. He was heartbroken. He really was, because he didn't want to divorce her. But Jane wanted it.

Ronald did better with Nancy

Ronald Reagan and Jane Wyman respected each other so much that they never discussed their marriage with others once they got divorced so anything you see written about it is likely to be pure speculation. The claim that Jane committed suicide was first made in the book Reagan: An American Journey by Bob Spitz but it was never substantiated. I think the video is based on the contents of the book.

The reasons for their divorce is disputed but the facts that are known include that Jane filed for divorce 3 months after their daughter Christine died. After losing their child, Jane was depressed and Ronnie offered her next to no support and instead spent most of his time at being the president of the Screen Actors Guild. Ronnie didn't want to get divorced but Jane wanted a more supportive husband.

Same here. And of course Wyman's films with Douglas Sirk had a special resonance in Germany because he was actually born in Hamburg (as Hans Detlef Sierck). Film students to this day still study his work and they continue to be influential - as seen in Todd Haynes films, most recent in Carol (2015).

German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder cited Sirk as his favourite director, e.g. the story and colourful cinematography in Lola (1981) clearly references to it. Mexican Director Guillermo del Toro even thanked Sirk in his speech at the 2018 Oscars!

Sirk's films have been quoted in films by directors such as Rainer Werner Fassbinder (whose Ali: Fear Eats the Soul is partly based on All That Heaven Allows) and, later, Quentin Tarantino, Todd Haynes, Pedro Almodóvar, Wong Kar-wai, David Lynch, John Waters and Lars von Trier.

More specifically, Almodóvar's vibrant use of color in 1988's Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown recalls the cinematography of Sirk's films of the 1950s, while Haynes' Far From Heaven was a conscious attempt to replicate a typical Sirk melodrama—in particular All That Heaven Allows. Tarantino paid homage to Sirk and his melodramatic style in Pulp Fiction, when character Vincent Vega, at a '50s-themed restaurant, orders the "Douglas Sirk steak" cooked "bloody as hell". Aki Kaurismäki alluded to Sirk as well; in his silent film, Juha, the villain's sport car is named "Sierck". Sirk was also one of the directors mentioned by Guillermo del Toro in his Oscar acceptance speech for Best Picture for The Shape of Water : "Growing up in Mexico as a kid, I was a big admirer of foreign film. Foreign film, like E.T., William Wyler, or Douglas Sirk, or Frank Capra."

Polyester (1981) directed by Waters was, according to Waters, informed by Sirk's Universal melodramas.

I want to clarify that many translated quotes from our falconcrest.org newsletters in this forum are apparently not in their original English wording, but oftentimes rephrased (which may result in misleading information) due to the obvious use of software-aided translations from Spanish and back to English. Hence, misunderstandings can occur.

The original language of our newsletters is English. The German version is the translated one (translated by native speakers). The information we share are not "stories", but facts based on production documents and information given from the cast, staff and crew. If we refer to rumors or gossip for a specific reason, we usually put this in the appropriate context to indicate why this particular information is shared. We pride ourselves in a high standard of journalistic integrity. Our Standards & Practices are here: https://falconcrest.org/english/master.php?path=show/episodes/ai/sp

As for the discussion about the reason for Jane having been cast...

It was, of course, primarily due to her respected previous work and her professionalism as an actress — although she was not the original choice for the rôle, as we discussed both in our "Behind the Scenes" section (https://falconcrest.org/english/master.php?path=show/episodes/ai/bts/tvy) and in the even more detailed newsletter about the changes from the original seasonal bibles to the final version, "The Secret FALCON Files" - Vol. 1 (https://falconcrest.org/english/master.php?path=show/episodes/ai/bts/secrets), which contains more names of actresses the producers discussed for the part.
